messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Tight Approximation Algorithms for Two-dimensional Guillotine Strip Packing

Paper Abstract: Abstract In the Strip Packing problem (SP), we are given a vertical half-strip [0,W]√ó[0,‚àû)0ùëä0[0,W]\times[0,\infty) and a set of nùëõn axis-aligned rectangles of width at most WùëäW. The goal is to find a non-overlapping packing of all rectangles into the strip such that the height of the packing is minimized. A well-studied and frequently used practical constraint is to allow only those packings that are guillotine separable, i.e., every rectangle in the packing can be obtained by recursively applying a sequence of edge-to-edge axis-parallel cuts (guillotine cuts) that do not intersect any item of the solution. In this paper, we study approximation algorithms for the Guillotine Strip Packing problem (GSP), i.e., the Strip Packing problem where we require additionally that the packing needs to be guillotine separable. This problem generalizes the classical Bin Packing problem and also makespan minimization on identical machines, and thus it is already strongly ùñ≠ùñØùñ≠ùñØ\mathsf{NP}-hard. Moreover, due to a reduction from the Partition problem, it is ùñ≠ùñØùñ≠ùñØ\mathsf{NP}-hard to obtain a polynomial-time (3/2‚àíŒµ)32ùúÄ(3/2-\varepsilon)-approximation algorithm for GSP for any Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 (exactly as Strip Packing). We provide a matching polynomial time (3/2+Œµ)32ùúÄ(3/2+\varepsilon)-approximation algorithm for GSP. Furthermore, we present a pseudo-polynomial time (1+Œµ)1ùúÄ(1+\varepsilon)-approximation algorithm for GSP. This is surprising as it is ùñ≠ùñØùñ≠ùñØ\mathsf{NP}-hard to obtain a (5/4‚àíŒµ)54ùúÄ(5/4-\varepsilon)-approximation algorithm for (general) Strip Packing in pseudo-polynomial time. Thus, our results essentially settle the approximability of GSP for both the polynomial and the pseudo-polynomial settings.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Approximation schemes for independent set and sparse subsets of polygons",
        "Orthogonal packings in two dimensions",
        "Bin packing in multiple dimensions: inapproximability results and approximation schemes",
        "Improved approximation algorithm for two-dimensional bin packing",
        "A tale of two dimensional bin packing",
        "An eda for the 2d knapsack problem with guillotine constraint",
        "OPT versus LOAD in dynamic storage allocation",
        "Fast approximation schemes for two-stage, two-dimensional bin packing",
        "Approximation and online algorithms for multidimensional bin packing: A survey",
        "An algorithm for two-dimensional cutting problems",
        "Combining dynamic programming with filtering to solve a four-stage two-dimensional guillotine-cut bounded knapsack problem",
        "Pattern-based diving heuristics for a two-dimensional guillotine cutting-stock problem with leftovers",
        "Performance bounds for level-oriented two-dimensional packing algorithms",
        "Peak demand minimization via sliced strip packing",
        "Algorithms for two-dimensional guillotine packing problems",
        "Exact algorithms for the two-dimensional guillotine knapsack",
        "Modeling two-dimensional guillotine cutting problems via integer programming",
        "A tight (3/2+œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon) approximation for skewed strip packing",
        "Approximation algorithms for demand strip packing",
        "Approximating geometric knapsack via L-packings",
        "Improved pseudo-polynomial-time approximation for strip packing",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for 2-dimensional knapsack: Packing into multiple l-shapes, spirals, and more",
        "A (2+œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon)-approximation algorithm for maximum independent set of rectangles",
        "‚Äústrong‚Äùnp-completeness results: Motivation, examples, and implications",
        "Multistage cutting stock problems of two and more dimensions",
        "A (5/3 + œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon)-approximation for strip packing",
        "Complexity and inapproximability results for parallel task scheduling and strip packing",
        "Approximation schemes for covering and packing problems in image processing and VLSI",
        "Closing the gap for pseudo-polynomial strip packing",
        "On rectangle packing: maximizing benefits",
        "A near-optimal solution to a two-dimensional cutting stock problem",
        "Approximation algorithms for multidimensional bin packing",
        "On guillotine separable packings for the two-dimensional geometric knapsack problem",
        "Tight approximation algorithms for geometric bin packing with skewed items",
        "Partial enumeration algorithms for two-dimensional bin packing problem with guillotine constraints",
        "Cutting the guillotine down to size",
        "Approximating maximum independent set for rectangles in the plane",
        "On approximating strip packing with a better ratio than 3/2",
        "Cutting glass",
        "Two-dimensional bin packing problem with guillotine restrictions",
        "Solving a real-world glass cutting problem",
        "Reverse-fit: A 2-optimal algorithm for packing rectangles",
        "Trim-loss minimization in a crepe-rubber mill; optimal solution versus heuristic in the 2 (3)-dimensional case",
        "The two-dimensional cutting stock problem revisited",
        "A 2.5 times optimal algorithm for packing in two dimensions",
        "A strip-packing algorithm with absolute performance bound 2",
        "Cutting and packing problems: a categorized, application-orientated research bibliography",
        "A bidirectional building approach for the 2d constrained guillotine knapsack packing problem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Tight Approximation Algorithms for Two-dimensional Guillotine Strip Packing, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
